title: Blackletter dominates NYC
content:
You’ve probably all seen this...

[http://blog.pentagram.com/archives/2007/07/sign\_of\_the\_times.php](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906232611/http:/blog.pentagram.com/archives/2007/07/sign_of_the_times.php "http://blog.pentagram.com/archives/2007/07/sign\_of\_the\_times.php")

...but what the Heller

Time for a Corona, I think.

Cheers, Si

 [‹ Interim release of Museum work-in-progress (my version of Centaur)](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906232611/http:/www.typophile.com/node/34838 "Go to previous forum topic") [sIFR 2 ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906232611/http:/www.typophile.com/node/35077 "Go to next forum topic")
author: sii

comments.content: Or several, given the temperatures you’re having to endure. But it is a beautiful sign, and exceptionally well crafted.

Not just blackletter, _raster_ blackletter. Awesome dude.

hhp
Cool. Thanks for the link. It’s a great example of an extremely simple solution that probably took an enormous amount of work to get to.

This  
 [http://blog.pentagram.com/archives/NYT\_Beaks\_Detail\_Sm.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20080906232611/http:/blog.pentagram.com/archives/NYT_Beaks_Detail_Sm.jpg "http://blog.pentagram.com/archives/NYT\_Beaks\_Detail\_Sm.jpg")  
is not “extremely simple”. It’s clever engineering (good design).

hhp
The story claims the text is Fraktur ... is that right? I would think it is more of a Textura.

<cite>The story claims the text is Fraktur ... is that right? I would think it is more of a Textura.</cite>

Yeah, it’s a Textura. But there’s some overlap between the two, so it’s easy for people who aren’t really into that stuff to confuse them.
Nobody comments on the use of both Comic Sans and Papyrus on the same menu?
No reason to question something that is \*obviously\* working so well. ;^)
I guess it proves that NYC isn’t as sophisticated as it may think it is.... :-)
